Chapter 9: Hearing and Upholding
The Buddha said to Bodhisattva Joyful King:
What are the six things of the perfection of hearing and upholding?
Seeing the poor and suffering who cannot save themselves, if one proclaims the Dharma and subdues them, causing the multitude to hear, this is called giving.

Always with the roots of virtue and practices of goodness, having personally practiced, one further encourages others. If one hears and does not uphold, one attains great wealth, this is called upholding the precepts.

If one hears good explanations and is able to endure various sufferings without regarding them as vexation, supposing a bodhisattva were a brahman, all from the foolish one obtains what is heard, cultivating for twelve years to give rise to and establish the unsurpassed great path, awakening to what is born, this is called patience.
If one is able to diligently abandon family affairs without regarding it as difficult, this is called vigor.
If one understands impermanence and hears the causes and conditions without being lazy, this is called concentration.
Learning without a teacher, skillfully equanimous towards all hatred and love, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six things of the perfection of long-distance crossing of birth and death?
If a donor attains the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, this is called giving.ğŸ”½If one is able to rely on supreme great compassion, this is called upholding the precepts.
If one uses gentleness to encourage vast vows, this is called patience.
If one uses extensive learning to give to all, this is called vigor.
If one is able to be tranquil and add to non-self, this is called concentration.
If one uses the lowly and even servants to teach and admonish with patience, gentleness, and vast samadhi, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six things of the perfection of non-interruption?
If one uses one's giving to establish the four kinds of kindness and rescue those in danger and distress, this is called giving.
The three are: guarding one's body, speech, and mind, always being careful. This is called upholding precepts.
If one harmonizes one's body and mind with the proper human way, and aspires to attain the forbearance of the Dharma, the four harmonious karmas, this is called forbearance.
If one diligently cultivates the four right efforts, without harming anything, all due to learning this and establishing true reality, this is called vigor.
If one attains the four bases of supernormal power through tranquility, this is called single-minded concentration.
If one cultivates the four noble truths with sagely wisdom without further falsehood, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of skillful means for the perfection of desire?
Giving away all one has without stinginess is called generosity.
Opening up merit and virtue to see the gate of liberation is called upholding precepts.

If one teaches and transforms with ultimate virtue, and the precepts and prohibitions are in one's practice and mind, and one opens up and delivers sentient beings by manifesting these precepts, and with forbearance and compliance one has a special harmony and ability to accept, this is called forbearance;
If one uses the Dharma to transform according to the times with various teachings, this is called vigor;
Understanding the appropriate time to practice the mind of kindness, practicing the four equalities to end others' suffering and joy, this is called meditation;
Desiring to teach and protect all sentient beings in accordance with the Dharma, arriving at the appropriate time without missing it, this is called wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six things of the perfection of meditation?
If one establishes one's giving wherever one desires without being able to go against it, this is called giving;
Keeping one's mind cautious and abandoning the unacceptable, this is called upholding the precepts;
Forbearing and harmonizing with the naturalness of all dharmas, entering into harmony and forbearance, this is called forbearance;
Diligent practice and contemplation, establishing and destroying all that is not, is zeal.
If one abandons what is heard through meditation, and with body, speech, and mind at ease, relies on the illumination of wisdom, this is concentration.
If one removes desires and with the virtue of holy wisdom eliminates various defiled practices, this is wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of spiritual powers?
If one gives lamps and thereby attains the reward of heavenly eyes that can see through, this is giving.
If one observes precepts and attentively listens to the sÅ«tras without violating them, thereby attaining the heavenly ear, this is observing precepts.
If one is kind and harmonious without duality and uses it to encourage and assist in giving rise to the intention for enlightenment, this is patience.

Accomplishing and attaining the recollection of past lives and past world events, with spiritual powers naturally for the sake of sentient beings dwelling in the world, accumulating merit and virtue, and restraining oneself in every life, this is zeal.

To embrace spiritual powers, supernatural powers, transformations, and unobtainable ultimates, to abandon attachment to various consciousnesses and accept equalized meditation, this is called concentration;

To attain this grace and its karmic retribution, to eliminate various defilements through wisdom and spiritual powers, and to thoroughly understand sagely illumination based on samÄdhi, this is called wisdom, exhausting all defilements;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of worldly skillfulness?

Not being able to encourage the study of the pÄramitÄs, only aspiring to worldly skillful techniques, engaging in other people's activities, using skillful techniques to make people cultivate virtue, this is called giving;
Later, to attain retribution and cause countless people to love and enjoy the path, this is called morality;
Being able to make all techniques and skills thoroughly understood without exception, this is called patience;
Swiftly practicing the bodhisattva's teachings and enabling accomplishment, this is called vigor;
If the mind is good, this is called concentration;
Consulting and receiving the Way and Dharma is prajÃ±Ä.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of loving kindness, compassion, and protecting all?
Using the mind to protect all beings with a compassionate mind is giving.

For the sake of beings, not being greedy for one's own body, using this precept to vow in a timely manner, and attaining freedom in the place of rebirth, teaching and transforming beings, and establishing the Way by following good deeds, is upholding the precepts.
Like the past king named MÄndhÄtá¹›, the vigor he aroused, the sorrow and thoughtfulness he cultivated in a timely manner, is patience.

If one becomes a king and someone seeks to cut off one's head, one's mind does not become angry. Countless people attain rebirth in the heavens. Through this vigor, if one is able to endure and also attain wealth and business, this is vigor.
The meditation of non-slothfulness, hiding nothing, and extinguishing the six sense objects, is concentration.

If one uses the wisdom of the sages to teach countless people, and everyone receives the great fruit of retribution, the dust and defilements of the six matters of various virtues are not seen to be encroached upon by the rewards of bravery, and there is no increase or decrease in the past, this is wisdom.
These are the six.
What is meant by the six matters of the perfection of compassion?
If one is able to give with a mind that spontaneously thinks to make all sentient beings universally at peace, this is giving.
If one abandons others and does not despise one's own body, completely dispersing all bonds, this is upholding the precepts.
If one is able to endure scolding and beating, and also transforms others to be patient, this is patience.

If one uses diligence to perfect the roots of various virtues, without being weary of the ultimate of the other shore, and further uses single-minded concentration to encourage the multitudes of people to leave the household life and study, this is diligence.
If one detests the evil destinies and loves the ultimate merit of dhyÄna concentration, this is meditation.
If one pities and purifies all impurities without slacking off, and if one gives the Dharma to teach and transform sentient beings, this is wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six aspects of the perfection of joy?
If one can practice kindness with a joyful mind without harboring resentment, this is giving.
If one has faith and observes the precepts to attain good virtue, this is morality.
If one accomplishes humility and shame without retaliating with coarseness, this is patience.
If one practices diligently with an unresentful mind, protecting oneself and others with good thoughts without harboring anger, this is vigor.
If one delights in tranquility with a pure mind, accomplishing the elimination of various desires, this is meditation.

To be generous without attachment, to practice the Dharma without expecting rewards, to contemplate wisdom and accept the factors of enlightenment, to select the factors of enlightenment and cultivate the door of liberation without wishes, to not dwell in inverted views and to not harm others - this is wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of encouraging protection?

To be generous without attachment, to uphold the Dharma of equality without harboring delusions - this is giving.ğŸ”½To be prudent and intimate with the factors of enlightenment, to accept diligence with a mind free from vexation - this is upholding the precepts.
To act without thought, with a mind that is bright and clear, to abandon greed and desire for both self and others - this is patience.
To understand conditioned phenomena and contemplate unconditioned phenomena without dwelling in duality - this is diligence.
To contemplate with meditative absorption and observe the power of tranquility and diligence, to be foremost in all places one goes - this is meditation.
If one has faith in the sages and follows the Way, and out of utmost compassion teaches and transforms others, this is wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of encouraging those with wrong views?
If one enters the shrines of various non-Buddhist teachings and follows their intentions to transform them, like the blessings and virtues created by the Brahmin SÅ«raá¹ƒgama, this is giving;
If one is bound by thieves and displays their practices to transform and liberate them, this is upholding the precepts;
If one is beset by various afflictions and does not become weary of them, this is patience;
If one gives and enters the mundane without being tainted by it, and proclaims the meaning of tranquility, this is vigor;
If one cultivates meditation and roams in darkness while delighting in it, delighting in the absence of delight and delighting in the Dharma, this is meditation;
If a brÄhmaá¹‡a-like person wishes to transform sentient beings, he follows their inclinations and teaches them accordingly. This is wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of encouraging right views?

If one enters into worldly customs and establishes the Dharma teaching, giving leads to blessings, upholding precepts leads to rebirth in the heavens, and all good and evil deeds have their own consequences. Using this to save them is called giving.
If there is no Buddha in the world, a bodhisattva has never followed the teachings of evil friends. This is called upholding precepts.
A bodhisattva is pure, clean, and flawless, like a snow-covered mountain giving birth to beautiful trees, where various gods, spirits, and dragons once played. This is called patience.
The diligent practice of removing self and other is like a merchant who travels far to accomplish his goals. This is called vigor.
If one cultivates the four dhyÄnas with wisdom and also protects them, this is called meditation.

If, with the sagely understanding, one has great compassion and pity for all sentient beings who have not yet attained [enlightenment], just as in the past one was taught by the original teachings, and with a single verse one instructs eighty-four thousand countries, this is wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of encouraging abiding in the view of liberation?
Even if a bodhisattva in a dream does not become stingy or jealous, and even if there is no different mind when the Buddha does not arise, how much more so in the present!
This is called giving.
If one encounters evil offenses and the loss of one's body and life, one never violates the precepts. This is called upholding the precepts.
The place where one is born is accompanied by light. As soon as one is born, one immediately hears the original pure forbearance and then attains the Buddha's path. This is called patience.
The place where one is born always sees the proclamation and transformation of sentient beings. With this Dharma path, one instructs others. This is called vigor.
In every life, one contemplates the Way well and establishes meritorious deeds, seeing the naturalness of one's original nature, thus attaining such [realization]. This is called concentration.

If one transcends the world and sees worldly affairs without a teacher or master, one stands alone and does not accept from others. Such wisdom always proclaims sincerity, and one's body, speech, and mind have never been deceptive. This is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of encouraging non-abiding?
If one uses expedient wisdom to rescue those in poverty and distress, this is called giving.
Carefully guarding body and mind, with a mind that does not violate and is not negligent, this is called morality.
Attaining the forbearance of non-arising and non-retrogression, this is called patience.
Contemplating that all myriad things are unobtainable, diligently cultivating skillful means without abiding, using this non-abiding to encourage the six pÄramitÄs, this is called vigor.

If one is not attached to anything internal or external, but sentient beings are confused and do not understand, conceiving of a self where there is no self, one should explain for them the realization of emptiness, this is called the one-pointed mind;
If one does not abandon the teachings of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, but relies on the wisdom of the sages, this is called wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of encouraging non-reliance?
If one gathers and bestows kindness, all the three realms will be delighted, just like the enlightenment of DÄ«paá¹ƒkara, this is called giving;
If one practices precepts without relying on anything and does not seek anything, this is called morality;
If one's mind is kind, gentle, and never deluded about any phenomena, this is called patience;
Diligent cultivation of practices without attachment, this is called vigor;
Seeing through meditation and entering the bodhisattva stage without falling into error, this is called meditation;
If one can eliminate all afflictions and return to the great Way with the wisdom of the sages, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six aspects of encouraging the perfection of intention?
If one thinks to oneself, 'The bodhisattva's salvation wishes to accomplish the Buddha-land and attain the ultimate,' this is called giving.
If one personally upholds the practice, cuts off the three evil destinies, and does not commit offenses, this is called upholding the precepts.
If one repays kindness with benevolence and compassion, and the marks of virtue are upright and wondrous, and all who see it rejoice, this is called patience.
If one diligently practices and enters the great ocean to obtain the wish-fulfilling jewel, exhausts all difficulties, and attains the Dharma of freedom, this is called vigor.
If one can eliminate afflictions through meditation and attain one's aspirations, this is called meditation.
If one can destroy the various demons with the wisdom of the sages and establish teachings that all follow, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six aspects of encouraging the perfection of forbearance?
If one gives away what one has obtained, keeping the mind of the Buddha's path in mind without ever forgetting it, this is called giving.
If one rescues the hells with a peaceful mind, and the demons cannot violate the Dharma without turning back, this is called upholding the precepts.

If one follows the principles and practices the right Dharma without harboring jealousy, like Prince Viry, who was generous and gave away everything he had in one day to the Buddha's disciples, wishing to obtain carriages, elephants, horses, and banners and canopies that filled forty li, as well as countless necklaces, robes, jewels, flowers, and incense, and gave away eighty-four thousand court ladies, abandoned the country and renounced the throne, and gave away his hands, feet, ears, nose, head, eyes, flesh, limbs, body, wife, and children without going against people's wishes, left home to become a Å›ramaá¹‡a, and upheld this right Dharma, this is called patience.
If one upholds the various precepts and practices diligently without attachment, this is called vigor.
If in dreams one sees many beautiful women but does not covet them, endowed with excellent physical characteristics and a pure countenance, this is called concentration;
If entering the city one harbors bright wisdom, and if seeing a bhiká¹£u one respectfully honors them without various thoughts, this is called wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six things of the perfection of creating karma?

If one establishes oneself in pure cultivation of the Brahma conduct, and what one encourages and assists brings much benefit, at the end of the Dharma's destruction one's robes barely cover one's body, like a flaming flower, one's studies and aspirations are lost, one's present body is destroyed and nothing is lost, five branches of new flowers and five branches of old flowers, also going up to the Buddha, by this retribution the Way's teachings flourish, the true Dharma is established up to five hundred years, and the semblance Dharma is also like this, this is called giving;
If with the many precepts one eliminates others' evil karmic actions, and according to their needs one rescues and delivers them, this is called upholding the precepts;

If one follows benevolence and harmony, even if there are obstacles and inauspicious events, one will surely be able to overcome them, just as a merchant entering the great ocean encounters a makara fish, and suddenly there are twenty-five bathing pools, each with a white elephant that one immediately rides to escape the great danger. This is called patience.

If one encounters the happiness and peace of the heavens and the world, just as in the past when there was no guiding master, wishing to be diligent, there was a great Brahma Heaven named Yingmiao, who inspired and transformed the Heavenly Emperor, teaching sentient beings to attain rebirth in the heavens. This is called diligence.

DhyÄna is unborn, expounded by the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas. If a Bodhisattva encourages sentient beings, causing them to be reborn in the Brahma Heaven, from the palace of Ä€bhÄsvara Heaven up to the Heaven of No-thought, this is called concentration.

The work of holy wisdom is to explain present-world affairs for the sake of worldly people and to expound the work of transcending the world, cultivating the ten wholesome actions and benefiting the multitude. It is like the ancient king named De Sheng, who had beautiful eyes and loved the Dharma. For countless lifetimes, he understood this meaning. The compassionate practices of the kings were initiated by the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas. By proclaiming this teaching to all, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six things of the perfection of not creating karma?

In the mind, happily delighting in meritorious virtues, at the beginning of all, encouraging giving with the mind. What can be encouraged is then attachment. In the past, the Bodhisattva saw DÄ«paá¹ƒkara Buddha and scattered five flowers in offering to the Buddha. The roots of virtue planted will all cause one to attain this meritorious virtue and morality, forever without delusion. Until the Dharma is extinguished, all will rely on it. This is called giving.
The learning is diligence;
If one uses body, speech, and mind without skillful means, and calculates that there are lands, places of birth and death, this is called upholding the precepts;
If one cultivates benevolence and joy, aspires for and seeks the root of suffering, this is called patience;
If one makes energetic progress and establishes worldly affairs, transforming them into the Dharma of the Way, this is called vigor;
If one cultivates meditation and observes the long and short lifespans of the Brahmas, this is called concentration;

If one follows the sagely and enlightened ones who have never spoken, like the bodhisattva named Tathagata-sun, who preaches a single type of Dharma according to the beings, while others preach various types, establishing tranquility and nirvana, and the true Dharma abides for many years before the Dharma is extinguished, this is called wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six matters of the perfection of remainder?
In the past, when the bodhisattva was under DÄ«paá¹ƒkara Buddha, he made offerings and served with the vow of the Way, this is called giving;
If one's body and speech have remaining attachments and abide in precepts, but have much disbelief and enjoy one's own body, this is called observing precepts.
If one's nature is kind and gentle, without coarseness or roughness, and returns to the power of solitary sitting, this is called patience.
If one cultivates in the middle, relying on and enjoying something, not reaching true reality, this is called vigor.
If one meditates and delights in attending to emptiness, not taking this as joy, this is called meditation.
If one hears of sagely wisdom and the mind has attachment or non-attachment, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What is meant by abiding in the pÄramitÄs with remainder?

If one cannot accord with truth but turns to other approaches, aiming for the realm of emptiness, the retribution of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, not cultivating the Buddha path, entering the stage of the ten grounds but then regressing, one should know that this mind is the practice of the bodhisattva with remaining pÄramitÄs.
What is meant by the bodhisattva's pÄramitÄs without remainder?

If one encourages sentient beings in the cycle of birth and death to repay their karmic consequences as much as they can bear, and remains silent and still in concentration without regressing, this is called giving.
If the karmic retribution of the precepts is apart from wisdom but one is able to deeply penetrate it, this is called upholding the precepts.
If one is benevolent and harmonious, fearing the evil destinies and places of hardship, and does not violate the mind, this is called patience.
If one diligently cultivates in order to seek the affairs of MÄra, wishing to eliminate its realm and make it devoid of evil roots, this is called vigor.
If one meditates in order to know the limits of one's lifespan and the ultimate origins, this is called meditation.
If one uses wisdom to see and know one's past lives, cutting off various sufferings and having good aspirations, this is called wisdom without remainder.
Why is it called 'without remainder'?
It means that the bodhisattva attains conformity with transformation and follows the world's preferences, and then it is called 'without remainder.'
What are the six matters of the perfection of wisdom?

When the bodhisattva practices giving to his superiors without expecting reward, even if he eats worldly food for a hundred thousand eons, he does not become depressed because of his body - this is called giving.

When he cultivates the meaning of the Dharma and goes to the Bodhi tree, he does not harbor doubts about any Dharma, and because of this, he attains the wisdom of compassion for all - this is called upholding the precepts.
When he meditates on the Dharma of non-attachment, this universal wisdom arises from this - this is called patience.
When he diligently practices and abides in the wisdom of the Way, transforming the five aggregates and obstructions, this is called vigor.
When he attains supreme perfect enlightenment through meditation and attains the heavenly eye, knowing his past lives and seeing what he has experienced, this is called single-minded concentration.
When he attains the wisdom of the sages and completely extinguishes the defilements, attaining the Buddha eye and fully understanding all dharmas without hesitation, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of abiding in illumination?
If one abides in the true Dharma, makes offerings to the Buddha's teachings, and upholds the scriptures, this is called giving.
If one enters the TathÄgata's body and mind, and is pure in speech without any thoughts, this is called upholding the precepts.
If one's practice is gentle and compliant, not close to worldly dharmas and unmoving, this is called patience.
If one understands the practices of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, eliminates various afflictions, and attains nirvÄá¹‡a, this is called vigor.
If one meditates in order to seek for sentient beings, and with the sounds of wisdom exhaust the mental activities, this is called meditation.
If one knows liberation and does not miss the right time to practice the sagely and bright compassion, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of accomplishing the arising?
When the Buddha appears in the world, he accomplishes great wealth and the sages are immeasurable, receiving the teachings of the buddhas of the past, this is called giving.
If one practices and encourages liberation, and when the Buddha appears in the world eliminates various afflictions, this is called upholding the precepts.
If one is benevolent and harmonious, accepts the teachings of the World-Honored One, knows contentment, and is free from laziness and great conduct, this is called patience.
If one diligently cultivates and establishes great vows, and if one's merit is like being in a king's position but the mind does not violate the Dharma, this is called vigor.
If one contemplates and always thinks of the Buddha without losing the truth, this is called meditation.
If one uses sagely wisdom to encourage liberation, like the Buddha's teaching and transforming the five people's body and mind, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of the perfection of non-disturbance of the mind?
If one practices kindness and as one wishes, vows to uphold the Way and transform others, this is called giving.
If one follows the ultimate practice to protect others and govern body, speech, and mind, this is called upholding precepts.
If one cultivates benevolence and harmony, this is profound patience. When the true Dharma is about to perish, one firmly resolves, this is called patience.
If one establishes diligent cultivation and embraces the wisdom of the Way with an undistracted mind, this is called vigor.
If one meditates and upholds emptiness, without thoughts or wishes, this is called concentration.
If one contemplates with sagely wisdom, feeling sorrow and pity, wishing to save all, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of establishing a home when the Buddha appears?
If one uses what is given to initiate five things, what are the five?

First, establishing the seat; second, the place of speaking; third, establishing the retinue; fourth, accomplishing the joy of the Dharma; fifth, establishing the written records. This is called giving.
If one establishes practice through giving, being fully restrained and not violating [the precepts], this is called morality.
If one, through kindness and harmony, abandons the notion of self and does not consider life and death, this is called patience.
If one diligently cultivates and follows impartial karma, revealing the meaning of the Way, this is called vigor.
Using the mind to contemplate and universally cultivate equality, practicing supreme virtue with an unaspiring mind, this is called concentration.
If with wisdom and clarity one returns to the noble truths and penetrates them all, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of leaving the household life?
If one gives with a mind that is in accord with the attainment of uncontaminated action, this is called giving.
If one is careful and protects body and speech, uniting with nirvana, this is called upholding precepts.
If one is benevolent and harmonious, weary of the three realms and without attachment, this is called patience.
Diligent cultivation of correct conduct, returning to the four abodes of mindfulness and giving rise to the intention for the Way, this is called vigor.
The reason for meditative concentration is to follow the four immeasurable minds, weary of the difficulties of transmigration through birth and death, this is called concentration.
If with noble clarity one lets go of far-off thoughts, abandoning sorrowful thoughts and cultivating the ultimate truth, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of great learning and compassion?
If one expounds the teachings with diligence and gives to those in poverty, this is called giving.
If one receives the Dharma and abandons one's body and life without greed or attachment, this is called upholding the precepts.

If one is kind and harmonious and the true Dharma is about to perish, the bodhisattva gives rise to the intention to follow the appropriate time and protects the true Dharma by sacrificing one's own life, this is called patience.
If one diligently cultivates and attains dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, always remembering without forgetting, this is called diligence.
If one contemplates and understands the twelve links of dependent origination without arising, this is called meditation.
If one uses wisdom to cultivate tranquility in all that one encounters, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of leaving the household and not abandoning the precepts?
If one benefits others according to their wishes and respectfully carries out the instructions of the Dharma master, this is called giving.
If one's practice of precepts is based on great compassion without the slightest resentment, this is called observing precepts;
If one's aspirations for benevolence and harmony are free from harm and danger, humble and respectful without arrogance, this is called practicing forbearance;
If one's diligent practice is strong and powerful without weakness, this is called practicing vigor;
If one's meditation and contemplation follow the seven factors of enlightenment, penetrating far and near without obstruction, this is called practicing meditation;
If one's aspirations for wisdom can fully attain the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, this is called practicing wisdom;
This is called the six pÄramitÄs. In the twelfth page of the previous text, the Dunhuang version has a note saying:
According to the heading, it omits the pÄramitÄ of the flourishing of the Buddha.
Chapter 10: Spiritual Powers The Buddha told Bodhisattva Joyful King:
What are the six things in abiding in the pÄramitÄ of spiritual powers?
If one gives generously, even to the point of giving up one's own life, without stinginess, and upholds the true teachings of the Way, this is called giving.
Practicing without attachment, not relying on right or wrong, and aspiring to the Great Way, this is called upholding the precepts.
Being kind and harmonious, free from doubt and forever without hesitation, this is called patience.
Aspiring to diligent cultivation, establishing great vows without going against one's original aspiration, this is called vigor.
The reason for meditative absorption is that its radiance illuminates far and near, this is called meditation.
The sagely wisdom that is followed accords with the stages of the Way, and every matter has a cause and is firmly upheld, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of spiritual powers without interruption?
If one rescues and establishes the TathÄgata's Buddha temple and shrine as the foremost, this is called giving.
Seeking the path and its fruits, attaining the root of wisdom and uprooting ignorance, this is called upholding the precepts.
Being gentle and sincere in one's aspirations, reaching the ultimate point, and giving rise to true enlightenment, this is patience.
Practicing diligently and penetrating through the notion of form without any thought, this is vigor.
Meditating in tranquil concentration up to the gates of liberation, this is meditation.
Following sagely wisdom and cultivating the practice of dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, observing right conduct and abiding in the land of simplicity, this is wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of entering into desire?
If one can rescue and gather forces to provide for one's enemies, this is giving.
If one's practice is weak and one gradually follows the power to establish great strength, this is morality.
If one can be gentle and sincere, dispelling hindrances and upholding the meaning of the Way, this is patience.
If one can sever hateful thoughts like a prince who delights in purity, this is vigor.
If one always meditates with an undistracted mind focused solely on concentration, this is meditation.
Therefore, the sagely and enlightened ones have something to liberate from the difficulties of the evil destinies, hells, and birth and death, diligently cultivating and making progress;
Just like the practices of the ancients, this is called wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six things of establishing liberation?
If a practitioner saves from the evil destinies, guiding those in birth and death to attain liberation like the reward of the crown protrusion, this is called giving;

If one practices and, when there is no Buddha in the world, enlightens the masses, causing each to attain their place, like the ancient sage king MahÄsammata who ruled the world with kindness, this is called upholding the precepts;

The reason for being kind and harmonious and not giving rise to anger, like when CÅ«dapanthaka had his hands, feet, ears, and nose cut off but did not give rise to a hateful mind, this is called patience;

Cultivating meditation as if in the inner palace, teaching and transforming noble people to give rise to the intention for the Way, surpassing the unequaled, like Prince Lion's freedom to issue commands like the wind bending the grass, this is called concentration;

If one enters the realm of the sage's wisdom and gives up everything, able to bestow it upon others without cutting off what is fortunate, like the ancient king who gave away his head as alms, this is called wisdom;

The gentleness one hears, like a brahman who wants to harm the king and take his head, immediately giving it to him, this is called patience;

Compassionately saving the people of the world, like VimalakÄ«rti transforming and purifying their conduct, this is giving;

Being benevolent and harmonious, never harboring resentment, and attaining the Buddha's path, this is called patience.

Following the sagely and bright, not discussing the wisdom of the Way, like the sandalwood tree in the ocean whose leaves emit a fragrant and delicious medicine for curing illnesses, the bodhisattva is like this, using the fragrance of morality to transform all beings and cause them to give rise to the mind of the great path, this is called wisdom.

The reason for their meditation, fully endowed with the four kinds, purifying the practice of kindness, compassion, joy and equanimity, this is called single-minded concentration;
Using wisdom to the utmost to accomplish what is difficult to attain, in the world rightly receiving the mind always in equal concentration, this is called wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of timely progress?
If one obtains a place to stay and sequentially gives relief to the many who are in distress, this is called giving.
If one is careful in one's actions, like being born among turtles, and when becoming the king of turtles one protects oneself and also saves others, this is called upholding the precepts.

If one's aspirations are benevolent and harmonious, closely following the practices of returning to protect body and speech, like a virtuous person practicing kindness and forbearance, cutting off all joints without holding any harm, this is called patience.

If one cultivates diligence, when the Buddha appears in the world one sees the Buddha everywhere, and the TathÄgata's samÄdhi seal is applied to all practices, for three thousand years without ever resting, this is called vigor.
If one's meditation is in the inner palace among the singing and dancing girls, always cultivating purity without being negligent, this is called single-minded concentration.

What are the six pÄramitÄs of the light?
If one offers flowers and incense without adornment to the buddhas and bodhisattvas, that is giving.

If one aspires to benevolence and understands all emptiness to attain the Dharma treasury, that is patience.

If one encourages the characteristics of the Dharma with kindness and harmony, without attachment, this is called patience.
If one diligently cultivates and practices the empty Dharma, encouraging the great path to return to this emptiness, this is called vigor.
If one uses meditation to assist in transforming sentient beings, always not slacking off and causing them not to regress, this is called meditation.
If one cultivates sagely wisdom and abides in the eighth ground, encouraging and transforming wherever one is without fail, this is called wisdom.

Cultivating meditation, using medicine to heal in the plague kalpa, like the deeds of the youth in the past, using the five heads to save Jambudvipa from evil, this is called concentration;

What are the six pÄramitÄs of entertainment?

What are the six pÄramitÄs of purity?
If one gives rise to something but does not rely on it, and also does not repay or add to sentient beings, this is called giving.
Practicing carefully and always holding firm faith, embracing the seven factors of enlightenment to awaken to all that is not yet awakened, this is called observing precepts.
Cultivating benevolence and compassion for sentient beings, not being greedy for one's own body or cherishing one's life, this is called practicing patience.
Aspiring to diligently cultivate and select all dharmas, gathering and attaining the supreme practices and the factors of enlightenment, this is called practicing diligence.

What are the six matters of the perfection of pure worldly conduct?

It means diligently practicing to protect many people and eliminating lust, anger, and ignorance, like the bright pearl in the ocean that dissolves water according to the season. This is diligence.

Cultivating sagely wisdom and having great compassion, like SubhÅ«ti seeing a different person capturing a deer king, with a retinue of five hundred, trapped in a difficult situation, completely liberating them, and then transforming all sentient beings in the world to establish the ten wholesome deeds. What are the six pÄramitÄs of the indestructible retinue?
If one abandons divisive speech, always speaks truthfully, and does not fight or cause trouble, this is giving.

What are the six pÄramitÄs of removing dust and coming to purity?

What are the six pÄramitÄs of observing the land?
Always embracing kindness and compassion, not harming others with the eyes, this is called giving.

What are the six pÄramitÄs of making vows?

If one gives to others and encourages them in the Way of the Sages, not in worldly affairs, this is giving;

If one uses kindness and compassion to proclaim the meaning of goodness, and if one throws oneself into a fire to endanger one's body but does not harbor resentment, this is patience;

What is meant by meditation is to eliminate all defilements and enjoy being alone, and if one uses the Dharma of precepts to save the ignorant masses, this is concentration;

What are the six pÄramitÄs of turning?
Generosity is to have abundant wealth and to extend compassion without harm. This is giving.

What are the six pÄramitÄs of the mind being without loss?
If one can subdue one's own mind and not follow wrong views, escape from the difficulties of the pit and not follow the calamities of greed, this is the reward of giving.

Chapter 11: The Thirty-two Marks The Buddha told Bodhisattva Priyankara:
What are the six things of the perfection of meditation on the level of truth?

These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of having soft and fine skin?
If one writes letters and texts, this is not tranquility, but using them to teach and transform all sentient beings, showing them the consequences of good and evil, this is the retribution of giving.

If one is endowed with the roots of virtue, and the wonderful spiritual light arises in the mind without extinction, this is the retribution of patience.
If one transcends the faults of the multitude of evils and attains the multitude of bodhisattvas who come to transform and guide, this is the retribution of vigor.
If one is without anger and resentment and attains merit, with a peaceful and joyful countenance, joyfully abiding in the Dharma with an unattached mind, this is the retribution of meditation.
If one abides in birth and death, being born in peace and transforming the multitude of ignorant ones, this is the retribution of wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of having flat feet?

If the soles of the feet are flat, wherever one goes there will be no difficulties, and the insects and moths underfoot will be forever at ease. If when raising the foot one is orderly, at ease, and by nature not impetuous or agitated, this is the reward of vigor.
When raising the foot, blessings lead to vastness, like empty space, in order to save sentient beings. This is the reward of meditation.
The soles of the feet are full, with flourishing merit and virtue without bounds. This is the reward of wisdom.

What are the six rewards of having long fingers?
The fingers are long and beautiful, due to virtues from past lives, without crookedness or impurity. This is all the merit and virtue of the rewards of giving, which is the reward of giving.

What are the six pÄramitÄs of having webbed hands and feet?
Hands and feet that are full, flat, and webbed between the fingers and toes are from fulfilling one's giving in past lives; this is the reward of giving;
Fingers and toes that are flat, upright, secure, and without crookedness, with a delighted mind when seen, are the rewards of upholding the precepts;
Hands and feet that are flawless, pure, and extremely beautiful, from practicing kindness and harmony in past lives, are the rewards of patience;
The Buddha's hands and feet are purple-golden in color, not accepting dust and dirt, due to diligently cultivating without laziness in the past, this is the reward of diligence;
The hands and feet are soft and without coarseness, lustrous and very beautiful, this is the reward of single-mindedness;
The hands and feet are radiant and bright, surpassing the common people, seeing which brings joy, this is the reward of wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of having flat knees?
The knees are upright, gradually turning upwards, all having differences, virtuous conduct is exceptional, seeing which brings respect, this is the reward of giving;

The knees are peaceful and do not rub against each other, this is the reward of upholding precepts;ğŸ”½The hands and feet are smooth and not advancing or retreating, all being appropriate and always present, this is the reward of patience;

Seeing it, everyone is delighted. The light and image are clear and distinct, which is the reward of wisdom.

What are the six things of the treasury of tranquility?
The treasury of tranquility is peaceful and harmonious. The light and color shine brightly but do not reveal the body, which is the reward of giving;
The tranquility is pure and moistening, benefiting everyone, which is the reward of upholding precepts;

The virtue is lofty and majestic. Wherever one goes, one transforms and liberates people, which is the reward of diligence;
The emitted light illuminates everywhere, bringing peace and security to many, which is the reward of concentration;
Causing others to see auspicious signs and embrace the unsurpassed sagely wisdom, which is the reward of wisdom;

What are the six things of the deep navel?
One's practice progresses daily, gradually reaching the profound, and then aspires for the great way, which is the reward of giving;
The virtue and spiritual power of being fearless and without worry is the reward of upholding precepts;
The practice of gentleness, depth, and peace is the reward of patience;
The practice of being complete without fear is the reward of diligence;
Also like beautiful flowers that are soft, harmonious, and focused without confusion, is the reward of concentration;
The navel being without damage, increasing all practices without loss, is the reward of wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of each hair growing to the right?
The hair growing upwards, curling to the right, pure and upright, following principle and independent, is the reward of giving;
The hair being dark blue, lustrous and beautiful, seen by all with joy, is the reward of upholding precepts;
The hair being soft, fine, smooth, and lustrous, is the reward of patience;
The color being lustrous and not accepting dirt or dust, is the reward of diligence;
The hair color being soft and beautiful, each curling to the right, is the reward of concentration;
Each waiting to be established, not suddenly violent, not pressing against each other, each being upright, this is the reward of wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six aspects of the perfection of purple golden color?
Its color is like the gold in fire, this is the reward of giving;ğŸ”½Its soft and moist color is not coarse, this is the reward of upholding precepts;

Its lack of dust and dirt is clear and bright, this is the reward of concentration;
Its soft and wonderful color is harmoniously radiant, this is the reward of wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six aspects of the perfection of a lion's chest?
Its body gradually fills without deficiency, this is the reward of giving;
The body is magnificent and wonderful, with lofty virtue, this is the reward of upholding precepts;
The body is firm and strong, with none who can violate it, this is called the reward of patience;
The eyes that all look up to and never tire of seeing are the reward of diligence;
The body that is vast and difficult to attain is the reward of concentration;
The body that is indestructible and firm like vajra is the reward of wisdom.
These are the six.

The body's actions that are complete and full are the reward of giving;
The unattainable auspiciousness that is fulfilled is the reward of precepts;
The joy and delight of seeing the supremely beautiful is the reward of patience;
The equal fulfillment of virtuous practices is the reward of diligence;
The marks and colors that are like the finest craftsmanship and beautiful paintings are the reward of meditation;
The pure and flawless radiance of gentleness is the reward of wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of the reward of long arms?

The fragrance of one's body is uninterrupted and universally renowned, this is the reward of giving;ğŸ”½Uprightly abiding in proper peacefulness and being unmoved, this is the reward of upholding precepts;
Harmonious, leisurely, firm, and unarisen, with a peaceful mind, this is the reward of patience;
If one naturally attains long and beautiful arms, surpassing the crowd, this is the reward of diligence;
Walking leisurely with long arms extending beyond the knees, revered by celestials and humans, this is the reward of concentration;
Manifesting a supple body with brilliant radiance illuminating all, this is the reward of wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of thighs?
If one's thighs are smooth and well-proportioned, with a kind heart and harmonious intentions, this is the reward of giving;
Standing alone, level and unmoved, always attaining freedom, this is the reward of upholding precepts;
Skillfully discerning places of peace and safety without calamity or difficulty, this is the reward of patience;
Having a straight body and gradually slender limbs is the reward of diligence;
Having majestic and lofty light and an invisible crown protrusion is the reward of concentration;
All sentient beings who look up to and admire it love and respect it, which is the reward of wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six things of the perfection of the fully filled brain?
Gradually becoming aware and accomplishing merit is the reward of giving;
Having a firm and peaceful mind is the reward of upholding precepts;
Being pure like a bright pearl that shines on its own is the reward of patience;
If one practices equally without laziness, it is the reward of diligence;
Having a peaceful mind and body is the reward of concentration;
Being moist and unbreakable by countless insults is the reward of wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six things of the perfection of the hook chain?
Always being harmonious and joyful when seeing those who seek is the reward of giving;
Gradually, through joy and understanding, dispelling the misunderstandings of the masses, this is the reward of upholding the precepts;
Each virtue being somewhat universally the same, relying on the Dharma of the Way to cultivate practice, this is the reward of patience;
If there is something to be said, all are silent, all equally accepting and happily practicing what is seen, this is the reward of diligence;
Its light is dark blue, shining far and wide, this is the reward of concentration;
If one can cause all sentient beings in the world to be liberated from the many calamities and bonds they are bound by, seeing them without becoming complacent, this is the reward of wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of having white teeth?
Teeth that are extremely white, closely set without gaps, this is the reward of giving;
Smooth, white, and spotless, this is the reward of upholding the precepts;
Following in sequence, like white lotus flowers, peaceful and even, this is the reward of patience;
Teeth that are firm, white, and without any black impurities, this is the reward of diligence;
Establishing vast peace and security in one's giving is the reward of concentration;
Having a body that is moist, soft, and radiant, with a light that is never tiring to behold, is the reward of wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of having even teeth?
Having even lower teeth without crookedness is the reward of giving;
Having both upper and lower teeth that are soft and free from coarseness is the reward of precepts;
Having teeth that fit together in sequence without gaps is the reward of patience;
Having teeth that are flat and even without high or low is the reward of diligence;
Having teeth that are not damaged but firm and strong is the reward of concentration;
Having lower teeth that are upright and upper teeth that are even is the reward of wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of having forty teeth?
Having forty teeth that are complete, even, and without deficiency is the reward of giving;
Teeth that are not crooked or leaning, but straight and even like water, is the reward of keeping the precepts;
Teeth that are wonderful and extraordinary, different from the common people, is the reward of patience;
Teeth that are sharp and penetrating, with no obstruction in between, evenly spaced and not loose, is the reward of diligence;
Teeth that are auspicious when born, with nothing unfavorable to see, is the reward of meditation;
Teeth that are very firm and unmoving, pleasing to the mind, is the reward of wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of the reward of a broad and long tongue?
When one is a bodhisattva, listening to the scriptures with the ears and selecting the ultimate words to speak, is the reward of giving;
Removing the impurities on the tongue and then transmitting the Buddha's words, proclaiming the pure meaning with the mouth, is the reward of keeping the precepts;
Speaking with the mouth in a balanced way, without partiality, is the reward of patience;
The tongue being extremely broad and long, the color like a lotus flower with a brilliant radiance, is the reward of diligence;
The marks that are born are wonderful and each is different, is the reward of meditation;
The tongue is like a hundred petals, with extraordinary radiance and color, shining far and wide, this is the reward of wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six things of the reward of the voice of BrahmÄ, which are the perfection of giving?
When practicing the bodhisattva path, proclaiming the scriptures, raising the voice to make the multitude hear clearly without doubt, this is the reward of giving;
The sound is lovable, hearing it brings joy, this is the reward of upholding the precepts;
The various kinds of sounds proclaimed are each different, this is the reward of patience;
The sound has never been heard before, and is incomparable, this is the reward of vigor;
The sound is always harmonious, the words are peaceful and not interrupted, this is the reward of meditation;
All the sounds are beautiful, sad and harmonious, moving the hearts of the multitude, this is the reward of wisdom;
These are the six.
The Buddha said:
Furthermore, Joyful King!
Always following and benefiting body and mind, making them peaceful and comfortable, this is the reward of giving;
If one's bodily actions, speech, and mind are tranquil and peaceful, this is the reward of upholding precepts;
If one gives rise to the ten wholesome [paths of action] and aspires to be born among humans and gods, making it one's way of practice, this is the reward of patience;
If one teaches and transforms the assembly without fault, this is the reward of vigor;
If one's compassionate and harmonious voice is gentle and mournful, addressing sentient beings, this is the reward of meditation;
If one proclaims the Dharma and resolves the doubts of the assembly, all are delighted, this is the reward of wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of the supreme flavor among flavors?
If one offers food and drink that is exceptionally delicious and pleasing to the masses, this is the reward of giving;
If those who receive the food attain peace and well-being without suffering, this is the reward of upholding precepts;
If the recipients harmonize with the donor's mind without contention, this is the reward of patience;
The offerings provided are equal in quantity, and the body is free from illness, this is the reward of diligence.
The food is extremely delicious, sweet in the mouth and without foul smells, this is the reward of concentration.
Not hot or cold, the taste is harmonious and pleasant, and it is light and soft, this is the reward of wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of the lion's cheek vehicle?
The back is broad and flat, shaped like a lion, and walks alone in the three realms, this is the reward of giving.
Like a lotus flower, the light and color are wonderful, and the conduct is like a lion, this is the reward of precepts.
If like a lion, advancing forward without fear or difficulty, this is the reward of patience.
The reason for manifesting the great deity is to be revered and admired, this is the reward of diligence.
The rest of what is proclaimed delights all beings and is respected by them, this is the reward of concentration.
Those who see his eyes cannot help but take refuge in him. His complexion is joyful, and those who see his virtue revere and respect him without satiation. This is the reward of wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six rewards for having eyes like a bull's or a moon's embrace to the utmost?
His eyes are subtle and wonderful, long and beautiful like the newly risen moon. This is the reward of giving.

His eyes are clear and good, lofty and without any shortcomings. This is the reward of upholding precepts.ğŸ”½His eyes are radiant, soft, fresh and wonderful, incomparably excellent. This is the reward of patience.
His face is without cowardice, with a lustrous glow. This is the reward of vigor.
His facial features are wonderful, his body is level and upright like the newly risen sun. This is the reward of meditation.
His radiance is like the sun and moon, illuminating the eight directions and the darkness above and below, none can surpass its brightness. This is the reward of wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six rewards for having deep blue eyes to the utmost?
If one sees the Buddha and is delighted in one's mind, and with a single thought returns to and respectfully gazes with the eyes, this is the reward of giving;
If what the eyes see is tranquil and still, without anything improper, this is the reward of upholding the precepts;
If the eyes are subtly beautiful and no one can criticize them, and those far and near are all subdued, this is the reward of patience;
If what the eyes see also causes no harm but brings much benefit, this is the reward of diligence;
If one sees far into the profound and resolves all bonds, this is the reward of single-mindedness;
If what one sees is inexhaustible and one sees equality, this is the reward of wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six matters of the perfection of the nose like a parrot?
If the nose is like a parrot, prominent, flat, upright, and wondrous, this is the reward of giving;

If one always abides in tranquility and stillness without any falsehood, this is the reward of upholding the precepts;ğŸ”½If the nose is beautiful, moist, and lustrous like a bright pearl, this is the reward of patience;
If it is soft, truthful, and benevolent, and its dignified demeanor is revered by all, this is the reward of diligence;
The respect and love of the multitude is inexhaustible and never satiated, this is the reward of concentration;
The mind abandons thoughts and experiences that cannot be relied upon, and does not dwell on various fragrances but takes the Way as fragrance, this is the reward of wisdom;
These are the six.

The hair grows blue-green like the color of the unsurpassed lapis lazuli, smooth and lustrous surpassing the light of lapis lazuli, this is the reward of giving;

Countless gods come to see and revere, bowing to the ground in self-surrender, this is the reward of patience;
Being able to protect oneself, with eyes unattached, this is the reward of vigor;
Soaring with heroic loftiness, spiritual powers boundless, this is the reward of concentration;
